title: How to Replace the Stereo in a 2005 Saturn Vue

steps.headline: Start by pressing the eject button and removing any disc that may be in it.
Disconnect the negative power cable from the car's battery.
steps.description: This is a wise step any time you're going to work on your car's electrical system.

steps.headline: Lift up on the trim around the shifter to disengage the clips.
steps.description: The trim should now easily move towards the back of the car.

steps.headline: Remove two screws on each side of the heated seat switches.
Pull on the trim around the stereo.
steps.description: There are clips on the top, bottom, and sides. Make sure you pull straight back towards the back of the car.

steps.headline: Disconnect all the cables on the trim and move it out of the way.
steps.description: Before you disconnect the cable to the temperature control, turn it all the way in one direction. This will make it easier to reconnect properly later.

steps.headline: Using a 7mm socket, remove the screws that hold the old stereo in place.
steps.description: There's one screw on each side. Disconnect the old stereo. In order to connect the new stereo, you'll need an adapter. The new stereo should come with a connector that fits it. You'll also need to buy a connector that fits your make, model, and year of car. Create your adapter by splicing the connectors together.

steps.headline: Install the new stereo into a dashboard kit that's designed for your make, model, and year of car.
Connect the new stereo.
steps.description: You need to make two connections, one for the antenna and one for the wiring harness.

steps.headline: Put the stereo into position.
steps.description: Be careful not to pinch any wires. Put in the screws in that hold the stereo in place.

steps.headline: Reconnect the battery and test the new stereo.
steps.description: Adjust the fade and balance controls to verify that each speaker is working correctly.

steps.headline: Reassemble the dashboard.
steps.description: Before reconnecting the temperature control, make sure the knob is in the same position it was in when you disconnected it.

tyn: A dashboard kit for the new stereo
A wiring harness adapter for the new stereo
A socket wrench with a 7mm socket and extension
text: Start by pressing the eject button and removing any disc that may be in it.  Disconnect the negative power cable from the car's battery. This is a wise step any time you're going to work on your car's electrical system. Lift up on the trim around the shifter to disengage the clips. The trim should now easily move towards the back of the car. Remove two screws on each side of the heated seat switches.  Pull on the trim around the stereo. There are clips on the top, bottom, and sides. Make sure you pull straight back towards the back of the car. Disconnect all the cables on the trim and move it out of the way. Before you disconnect the cable to the temperature control, turn it all the way in one direction. This will make it easier to reconnect properly later. Using a 7mm socket, remove the screws that hold the old stereo in place. There's one screw on each side. Disconnect the old stereo. In order to connect the new stereo, you'll need an adapter. The new stereo should come with a connector that fits it. You'll also need to buy a connector that fits your make, model, and year of car. Create your adapter by splicing the connectors together. Install the new stereo into a dashboard kit that's designed for your make, model, and year of car. Follow the kit's instructions. Connect the new stereo. You need to make two connections, one for the antenna and one for the wiring harness. Put the stereo into position. Be careful not to pinch any wires. Put in the screws in that hold the stereo in place. Reconnect the battery and test the new stereo. Adjust the fade and balance controls to verify that each speaker is working correctly. Reassemble the dashboard. Before reconnecting the temperature control, make sure the knob is in the same position it was in when you disconnected it.
sentences: Start by pressing the eject button and removing any disc that may be in it.
Disconnect the negative power cable from the car's battery.
This is a wise step any time you're going to work on your car's electrical system.
Lift up on the trim around the shifter to disengage the clips.
The trim should now easily move towards the back of the car.
Remove two screws on each side of the heated seat switches.
Pull on the trim around the stereo.
There are clips on the top, bottom, and sides.
Make sure you pull straight back towards the back of the car.
Disconnect all the cables on the trim and move it out of the way.
Before you disconnect the cable to the temperature control, turn it all the way in one direction.
This will make it easier to reconnect properly later.
Using a 7mm socket, remove the screws that hold the old stereo in place.
There's one screw on each side.
Disconnect the old stereo.
In order to connect the new stereo, you'll need an adapter.
The new stereo should come with a connector that fits it.
You'll also need to buy a connector that fits your make, model, and year of car.
Create your adapter by splicing the connectors together.
Install the new stereo into a dashboard kit that's designed for your make, model, and year of car.
Follow the kit's instructions.
Connect the new stereo.
You need to make two connections, one for the antenna and one for the wiring harness.
Put the stereo into position.
Be careful not to pinch any wires.
Put in the screws in that hold the stereo in place.
Reconnect the battery and test the new stereo.
Adjust the fade and balance controls to verify that each speaker is working correctly.
Reassemble the dashboard.
Before reconnecting the temperature control, make sure the knob is in the same position it was in when you disconnected it.
